awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF-supported Jicamarca Radio Observatory (JRO) in Peru has been operational for over 50 years. This major center for upper atmospheric research, training, and education, currently facilitating the research efforts of  investigators supported by  NSF's Geospace Programs, NASA, and the U.S. Air Force. The observatory participates in the World Day investigations, which is a globally coordinated observing effort where participating radars make simultaneous measurements of the upper atmosphere. The observatory also performs specialized experiments, maintains a large instrument cluster in partnerships with other investigators, hosts visitors at different professional levels, and conducts internship programs and schools in aeronomy and space weather. JRO is also preparing to support NASA's ICON (Ionospheric Connection Explorer) and GOLD (Global-scale Observations of the Limb and Disk) missions as well as a NASA sounding rocket campaign in Peru planned tentatively for 2022. This award will support upgrades to the facility to maintain its historically highly productive status. These upgrades are to complete the final half of electronic antenna beam steering upgrade, to entirely replace the deteriorating ground screen that the main antenna sits above, and to upgrade obsolete tube amplifiers to solid state amplifiers which will increase the power output of the antenna.

Jicamarca is the foremost ground-based instrument for studying the equatorial ionophere and can observe echoes from the lower, middle, and upper atmosphere, ionosphere, topside, and plasmasphere to an altitude of nearly 10,000 km. Jicamarca is unique because if its high power (50-MHz operating frequency), its modularity, and its proximity to the magnetic equator. The frequency allows it to probe both exceptionally low and exceptionally high altitudes compared to other mesosphere-stratosphere-troposphere (MST)/incoherent scatter radars, in a region with few instruments. The capabilities permit discovery research even after several decades of operation but are suffering from the postponement of essential maintenance and upgrades. The new ground screen will improve the gain and the beam shape which directly impacts pointing precision. The beam steering and switching capability along with increased power will enable new and improved experiments to be carried out including monitoring of equatorial spread F and of mesosphere-stratosphere-troposphere winds and turbulence, as well as planetary and solar radar experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This was a project to perform crucial, timely upgrades at the Jicamarca Radio Observatory, the foremost facility for studying aeronomy, space physics, and space weather at the magnetic equator. The upgrade had three main components intended to improve the performance and the longevity of the facility. The outcomes of this project may be organized along the lines of these three components. Thanks to the upgrade, the Jicamarca facility is now better prepared to pursue its scientific objectives than at any other time in recent memory.

1. Replacing two of the four legacy driver amplifiers at Jicamarca with solid-state units. The old amplifiers are based on vacuum tubes for which there are no spares and no replacements available on the market (for many years). Whereas the old amplifiers represented single-point failures, the new amplifiers will be be reliable, repairable, and able to run with little intervention for extended periods of time. This will facilitate new medium power, extended duration runs. Such runs are required for space-weather forecasting which depends upon continuous ISR datasets. The two new solid-state driver amplifier units are now in place.

2. Implementing electronic beam steering on the full main antenna array for the first time. The legacy mechanical beam steering system has a number of critical faults. First, it limits the kinds of experiments we can perform. For example, whereas plasma density, temperature, and composition is best measured with the radar beam steered obliquely to the magnetic field direction, drifts are best measured with the beam steered perpendicular to B. In order to make both measurements simultaneously, the antenna has to be divided into halves, compromising the sensitivity of both experiments. Likewise, solar radar experiments require different beam pointing directions for transmission and reception, and only a fraction of the main antenna can be used for either with mechanical steering.

Second, the legacy beam steering system is inflexible. The observatory has a fixed number of phase-delay cables which can only be arranged into so many combinations. The current system is a two-bit system with 90-degree phase quantization. The new system will be a three-bit system with unrestricted combinatorics, and the resulting pointing positions will be more numerous and have improved directivities generally.

Third, mechanical beam steering with the legacy system requires considerable labor, is prone to human error, and is something human beings should not be doing in the 21st century. Replacing it with an electronic system will modernize the observatory, its experiments, and the way it utilizes its staff.

The beam-switching hardware and related software required for this project was developed, fabricated, and deployed. We look forward to the scientific benefits this will facilitate.

3. Replacing the main antenna ground screen. The original screen was made of chicken wire and has deteriorated. It had become a hazard. The new screen, made of a stronger metal mesh, will improve antenna performance (gain), uniformity, and predictability while mitigating the safety hazard posed by the old screen.
